Kathleen Sebelius to suggest borrowing $225 million from other accounts throughout state government. But the move required approval from legislative leaders, and Republican leaders refused Monday.

content: Unless you live in Kansas, I'd suggest you stuff it. The state is not bankrupt. I'm a state employee of Kansas, and we got paid on time the week before last, and we're getting paid on time this week. Our state is NOT BANKRUPT. The problem occurred when the money for pay was not available in the usual account, and Republicans wanted to block the transfer of funds from one account to the other. We HAD THE FUNDS. The Republicans couldn't have cared less whether or not we got paid, and our Governor fought for the workers to make sure we got paid in a timely manner. The money was transferred, the hard-working employees got paid, and the state is still - c'mon people, say it with me - NOT BANKRUPT. Other than our governor, who is VERY popular in this state, our legislature is mostly Republican. Don't go waving fingers at Democrats. Our Governor has been working her butt off with the legislature to balance the budget and not be forced to fire employees. She didn't make this financial mess, but she's doing the best job possible to balance it.

Our Governor has been working her butt off with the legislature to balance the budget and not be forced to fire employees. She didn't make this financial mess, but she's doing the best job possible to balance it.

content: quote: Originally posted by ArtMarsh: Now I didn't know you were a Kansan... Where abouts? KC, KS. quote: BTW: I have been trying to figure out what the legislature was thinking when they blocked the transfer. Do you have any ideas? It isn't like the governor wasn't going to sign the budget amendment that was the supposed reason for this blockage... It really makes no sense other than the legislature was attempting to put the Governor back into "her place" and show her who had the real power in Kansas government. You just hit the nail on the head, actually. It was a power-play. A gang of unpopular local representatives, trying to push the governor around at the expense of working folks. Basically, they wanted to do anything they could to make it harder for the governor, to make her look bad, and to make people think it's her fault. Of course, most of us know better. They also wanted to back her into a corner to get her to agree to some of their political demands, almost like political black-mail, using state employees as a bargaining chip. Cheap tactic, I'd say. quote: Real wierd... I have asked my family there and they do not know either. All the people who work with me were discussing it in-depth. Personal partisan politics aside, everyone agreed that the governor was doing the best she possibly could, and that the republican legislature was, as a group, being a bunch of jerks. Where I work, I know we're all doing everything we can to trim the budget without firing anyone. We're trying to formulate a budget that's even tighter than the one we've been told to anticipate, and the intent is to avoid both layoffs and furloughs. We'd go to furloughs before we'd go to layoffs. Our institution and the state both know that if even more people are out of work, things will go downhill even faster (fewer dollars to spend, even more businesses laying off people, less tax money... downward spiral), so we're doing everything we can to keep everyone on board. We'll fix equipment instead of getting new stuff. We'll recycle more. We'll consolidate supplies and projects whenever possible. We're taking care of ourselves, and our governor is taking care of her end of the bargain. I hope she doesn't take the nomination. Kansas needs her more.
quote: Originally posted by ArtMarsh: Now I didn't know you were a Kansan... Where abouts?
reply: KC, KS. quote: BTW: I have been trying to figure out what the legislature was thinking when they blocked the transfer. Do you have any ideas? It isn't like the governor wasn't going to sign the budget amendment that was the supposed reason for this blockage... It really makes no sense other than the legislature was attempting to put the Governor back into "her place" and show her who had the real power in Kansas government. You just hit the nail on the head, actually. It was a power-play. A gang of unpopular local representatives, trying to push the governor around at the expense of working folks. Basically, they wanted to do anything they could to make it harder for the governor, to make her look bad, and to make people think it's her fault. Of course, most of us know better. They also wanted to back her into a corner to get her to agree to some of their political demands, almost like political black-mail, using state employees as a bargaining chip. Cheap tactic, I'd say. quote: Real wierd... I have asked my family there and they do not know either. All the people who work with me were discussing it in-depth. Personal partisan politics aside, everyone agreed that the governor was doing the best she possibly could, and that the republican legislature was, as a group, being a bunch of jerks. Where I work, I know we're all doing everything we can to trim the budget without firing anyone. We're trying to formulate a budget that's even tighter than the one we've been told to anticipate, and the intent is to avoid both layoffs and furloughs. We'd go to furloughs before we'd go to layoffs. Our institution and the state both know that if even more people are out of work, things will go downhill even faster (fewer dollars to spend, even more businesses laying off people, less tax money... downward spiral), so we're doing everything we can to keep everyone on board. We'll fix equipment instead of getting new stuff. We'll recycle more. We'll consolidate supplies and projects whenever possible. We're taking care of ourselves, and our governor is taking care of her end of the bargain. I hope she doesn't take the nomination. Kansas needs her more.
title: How can the Gov of a Bankrupt state be considered for a cabinet level post

content: quote: Originally posted by Whirled_Peas: Unless you live in Kansas, I'd suggest you stuff it. The state is not bankrupt. I'm a state employee of Kansas, and we got paid on time the week before last, and we're getting paid on time this week. Our state is NOT BANKRUPT. The problem occurred when the money for pay was not available in the usual account, and Republicans wanted to block the transfer of funds from one account to the other. We HAD THE FUNDS. The Republicans couldn't have cared less whether or not we got paid, and our Governor fought for the workers to make sure we got paid in a timely manner. The money was transferred, the hard-working employees got paid, and the state is still - c'mon people, say it with me - NOT BANKRUPT. Other than our governor, who is VERY popular in this state, our legislature is mostly Republican. Don't go waving fingers at Democrats. Our Governor has been working her butt off with the legislature to balance the budget and not be forced to fire employees. She didn't make this financial mess, but she's doing the best job possible to balance it. That's basically what I said...

content: Unless you live in Kansas, I'd suggest you stuff it. The state is not bankrupt. I'm a state employee of Kansas, and we got paid on time the week before last, and we're getting paid on time this week. Our state is NOT BANKRUPT. The problem occurred when the money for pay was not available in the usual account, and Republicans wanted to block the transfer of funds from one account to the other. We HAD THE FUNDS. The Republicans couldn't have cared less whether or not we got paid, and our Governor fought for the workers to make sure we got paid in a timely manner. The money was transferred, the hard-working employees got paid, and the state is still - c'mon people, say it with me - NOT BANKRUPT. Other than our governor, who is VERY popular in this state, our legislature is mostly Republican. Don't go waving fingers at Democrats. Our Governor has been working her butt off with the legislature to balance the budget and not be forced to fire employees. She didn't make this financial mess, but she's doing the best job possible to balance it.

Either way… the Republicans in that state came out looking very sh! Tty. From what I understand it was over budget items. The Repub legislature has spending priorities that differ from the Dem Governor. Refusing to move money around the various silos has everything to do with their dislike of her budget priorities. Nope... it was all about getting the Republican's last spending bill signed. Something that apparently she was going to do anyway. Once she signed the bill... the legislature okayed the fund transfer... from the original requested account.
quote: Originally posted by floersh: quote: Originally posted by ArtMarsh: This was completely bazaar in that there was no reason for this demonstration by the Republican led legislature. The only thing I can think of is that they were trying to show the popular Governor who was really the boss (in the state). Much akin to a group of school yard bullies preying upon anyone perceived to be weaker… or a wolf pack in ganging up to take down stronger prey. Either way… the Republicans in that state came out looking very sh! Tty. From what I understand it was over budget items. The Repub legislature has spending priorities that differ from the Dem Governor. Refusing to move money around the various silos has everything to do with their dislike of her budget priorities.
reply: Nope... it was all about getting the Republican's last spending bill signed. Something that apparently she was going to do anyway. Once she signed the bill... the legislature okayed the fund transfer... from the original requested account.
title: How can the Gov of a Bankrupt state be considered for a cabinet level post

content: quote: Originally posted by ArtMarsh: Now I didn't know you were a Kansan... Where abouts? KC, KS. quote: BTW: I have been trying to figure out what the legislature was thinking when they blocked the transfer. Do you have any ideas? It isn't like the governor wasn't going to sign the budget amendment that was the supposed reason for this blockage... It really makes no sense other than the legislature was attempting to put the Governor back into "her place" and show her who had the real power in Kansas government. You just hit the nail on the head, actually. It was a power-play. A gang of unpopular local representatives, trying to push the governor around at the expense of working folks. Basically, they wanted to do anything they could to make it harder for the governor, to make her look bad, and to make people think it's her fault. Of course, most of us know better. They also wanted to back her into a corner to get her to agree to some of their political demands, almost like political black-mail, using state employees as a bargaining chip. Cheap tactic, I'd say. quote: Real wierd... I have asked my family there and they do not know either. All the people who work with me were discussing it in-depth. Personal partisan politics aside, everyone agreed that the governor was doing the best she possibly could, and that the republican legislature was, as a group, being a bunch of jerks. Where I work, I know we're all doing everything we can to trim the budget without firing anyone. We're trying to formulate a budget that's even tighter than the one we've been told to anticipate, and the intent is to avoid both layoffs and furloughs. We'd go to furloughs before we'd go to layoffs. Our institution and the state both know that if even more people are out of work, things will go downhill even faster (fewer dollars to spend, even more businesses laying off people, less tax money... downward spiral), so we're doing everything we can to keep everyone on board. We'll fix equipment instead of getting new stuff. We'll recycle more. We'll consolidate supplies and projects whenever possible. We're taking care of ourselves, and our governor is taking care of her end of the bargain. I hope she doesn't take the nomination. Kansas needs her more.
quote: Originally posted by ArtMarsh: Now I didn't know you were a Kansan... Where abouts?
reply: KC, KS. quote: BTW: I have been trying to figure out what the legislature was thinking when they blocked the transfer. Do you have any ideas? We'd go to furloughs before we'd go to layoffs. Our institution and the state both know that if even more people are out of work, things will go downhill even faster (fewer dollars to spend, even more businesses laying off people, less tax money... downward spiral), so we're doing everything we can to keep everyone on board. We'll fix equipment instead of getting new stuff. We'll recycle more. We'll consolidate supplies and projects whenever possible. We're taking care of ourselves, and our governor is taking care of her end of the bargain. I hope she doesn't take the nomination. Kansas needs her more.

title: How can the Gov of a Bankrupt state be considered for a cabinet level post

content: quote: Originally posted by Whirled_Peas: Unless you live in Kansas, I'd suggest you stuff it. The state is not bankrupt. I'm a state employee of Kansas, and we got paid on time the week before last, and we're getting paid on time this week. Our state is NOT BANKRUPT. The problem occurred when the money for pay was not available in the usual account, and Republicans wanted to block the transfer of funds from one account to the other. We HAD THE FUNDS. The Republicans couldn't have cared less whether or not we got paid, and our Governor fought for the workers to make sure we got paid in a timely manner. The money was transferred, the hard-working employees got paid, and the state is still - c'mon people, say it with me - NOT BANKRUPT. Other than our governor, who is VERY popular in this state, our legislature is mostly Republican. Don't go waving fingers at Democrats. Our Governor has been working her butt off with the legislature to balance the budget and not be forced to fire employees. She didn't make this financial mess, but she's doing the best job possible to balance it. That's basically what I said...
quote: Originally posted by Whirled_Peas: Unless you live in Kansas, I'd suggest you stuff it. The state is not bankrupt. The money was transferred, the hard-working employees got paid, and the state is still - c'mon people, say it with me - NOT BANKRUPT. Other than our governor, who is VERY popular in this state, our legislature is mostly Republican. Don't go waving fingers at Democrats. Our Governor has been working her butt off with the legislature to balance the budget and not be forced to fire employees. She didn't make this financial mess, but she's doing the best job possible to balance it.
